LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL. 
  DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR, 
BuR&AU OF EDUCATION, 
Washington, D. C., July 11, 1893. 
Str: I have the honor to transmit for publication a catalog of a 
model library of 5000 volumes selected by experts of the American 
Library Association, and representing as nearly as possible the 5000 
books that a new library ought to obtain first for its collection. Inas- 
much as many States have laws permitting the establishment of public 
libraries by cities and towns, and the support thereof by taxation, the 
public library has become one of the most important of our educational 
institutions. This catalog, itis hoped, will supply a need that is widely 
felt for expert advice in making the first collection of books. 
Our people are justly proud of the American Library Association, 
which, by its zeal and practical energy, has done so much to devise 
means for the successful management of libraries. This Association 
has given its time and assisted this office with money to procure and 
install a model library of 5000 volumes, which forms a part of the 
exhibit of the Bureau of Education at the Columbian Exposition, The 
Association has crowned its labors by preparing a model catalog and 
supervising the proofs while in press. This catalog does much more 
than show a desirable list of books. It shows two very complete sys- 
tems of classification, and in this respect is the most instructive vol- 
ume yet printed on the subject of libraries. 
Respectfully submitted, 
W. T. Harris, 
Commissioner. 
Hon. Hoke Smrra, 
Secretary of the Interior.
-P-A-G-E-6

-P-A-G-E-7
ENG ROE. 1 O:N:. 
The value of a carefully selected list of books adapted to the needs of 
a small public library and suitable as a basis for a larger collection, has 
long been recognized by the American Library Association. TheColum- 
bian Exposition has proved the oceasion, and the hearty codperation of 
the U. S, Bureau of Education the means of carrying out the plan. 
The American Library Association voted, in September, 1890, to make 
an exhibit at the Columbian Exposition, of which an important feature 
should be a model or A. L. A. library. A selection of 5000 volumes 
was made by a committee who passed upon the suggestions of about 
seventy-five librarians and specialists. The publishers have given the 
books selected, The Bureau of Education has contributed the greater 
part of the expense of the exhibit, which is made under its auspices in 
the United States Government Building. The library has been put in 
complete working order, showing the most approved methods in shely- 
ing, cataloging and issuing books. At the close of the Exposition it 
will be deposited permanently with the Bureau of Education in Wash- 
ington, where it will furnish a practical object lesson of great value. 
The printed catalog is designed to be of practical service to librarians 
(1) in the selection and purchase of books, and (2) in classification and 
cataloging. 
SELECTION AND PURCHASE. 
The committee would disclaim the idea that this is a model library, 
in the sense of being an ideal selection. The wealth of material and 
the differences of opinion are such that no such selection is possible. 
They would claim, however, that it is a good working library, repre- 
senting the best thought of competent judges in various departments. 
No board of trustees would make a mistake in ordering the collection 
as it stands. The number of volumes in each subject is the result of 
careful study, and editions as well as works have been indicated. The 
number of books in photography is large for a library of 5000 volumes. 
It illustrates a special collection. Every library should have such a 
collection on some subject of general or local interest. 
vil

CLASSIFICATION AND CATALOGING. 
This catalog will be of service in supplying the proper class num- 
bers, dictionary headings, and author entries to libraries, using in 
whole or in part this selection of books. The most costly item in put- 
ting a library in order is thus saved. 
The catalog is divided into three parts: Part 1, classed catalog ac- 
cording to the Decimal classification; part 2, classed catalog according 
to the Expansive classification; part 3, Dictionary catalog. Part 1 is 
preceded by alphabetical lists of biography and fiction. The question 
whether a classed or a dictionary catalog is more useful is still unsettled, 
though much has been written on the subject. (See U. S. Bureau of 
Education, Public libraries in the United States, pp. 526-662.) Hach 
has advantages; each is useful if well made. Several public libraries 
of good standing use a card dictionary catalog and a classed printed 
finding list. For usages of a large number of libraries, see statistics vol- 
ume “Cataloging” in the comparative library exhibit. 
The printed catalog has been prepared at the New York State 
Library, under the direction of Mary S. Cutler, chairman of the Ex- 
position committee. The work has been done by Louisa S. Cutler, of 
the Library School class of 1889, assisted by Henrietta Church and 
Bessie Baker, of the class of 1893.* The classification of books by the 
Decimal system has been done by Walter S. Biscoe, who has a more 
thorough acquaintance with its practical workings than any other 
person. The classification by the Expansive system has been revised 
by the author, C. A. Cutter. The dictionary catalog has been revised 
by Harriet C. Blake, formerly at the Boston Public Library. Proof- 
*To be found in United States Government building, Chicago, until November is 
1893; afterwards at New York State Library School, Albany. 
   
-P-A-G-E-9
INTRODUCTION. Ix 
reading has been done by the chairman, assisted by William S. Burns, 
of the Library School class of 1891. The cataloguing rules prepared 
by the American Library Association have been followed. The entry 
under the pseudonym and under the shorter, better known form of the 
author’s name follows Cutter’s Rules for a. Dictionary Catalog, third 
edition. There is a growing usage in this direction. Prices of books 
and information in regard to books out of print have in most cases 
been secured directly from the publishers. 
The imprint has been given in this catalog with more fulness than 
the average library could afford to followin printing afinding list. Facts 
should be omitted in the following order: (1) price; (2) publisher’s 
nameé® (3) size; (4) date of publication. The call number, author, 
brief title and number of volumes must appear in every finding list, 
however brief. The most useful addition of facts would be (1) illus, (illus- 
trated); (2) number of pages. A table of contents should be substituted 
instead of the Outlines of Decimal and Expansive classifications, given 
on pp. 39 and 145. 
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS. 
Acknowledgments are due (1) to the following for money contrib- 
uted to supplement the appropriations of the Bureau of Education 
for cataloging the A. L. A. library: Massachusetts World’s Fair Com- 
mission, E. C. Hovey, R: R. Bowker, Osterhout Free Library (Wilkes- 
Barre, Pa.), Hannah P. James, and John M. Glenn; (2) to the New 
York State Library, for large contributions of time; (3) to the pub- 
lishers of the selected books who have given a large proportion of the 
library. The committee would make a special acknowledgment of the 
hearty and generous spirit which has characterized these gifts. The 
books thus donated are exhibited at Chicago and appear throughout 
the catalog in Roman type; books selected but not exhibited appear in 
italics. It is evident that the committee can not vouch for the accuracy 
of entries in italics. 
Any person using this catalog will render a real service by reporting 
criticisms and corrections of whatever sort. These should be sent to 
Mary S. Cutler, State Library, Albany, N. Y. 
ADDRESSES OF PUBLISHERS. 
Roman type indicates publishers who have presented to the exhibit library the works published by 
them, which appear in the following catalog. 
Publishers are referred to in the catalog which follows by the first name in firm title. 
When books are supplied by an agent instead of directly by the publisher, the name of the agent 
of whom the book should be ordered follows the publisher’s in ( ). 
When a book is presented in a more costly edition or binding, its price is given, followed by the 
price of the ordinary edition.

-P-A-G-E-17
        DIRECTIONS, OF THE COMMITTEE FOR 
PURCHASE AND ARRANGEMENT 
OF A. L. A. LIBRARY 
The library exhibit at Chicago justified its formation by a strong and 
intelligent interest on the part of hundreds of visitors, many of them 
trustees and librarians of small libraries. The questions asked from 
June 1 to November 1 by inquirers from all parts of the country have 
suggested the following directions based on the methods adopted by 
the exposition committee in putting the A. L. A. library in order for 
exhibition at Chicago: 
1. Order the books through one agent in your own town or in one of 
the publishing centers. 
2. Order all necessary supplies that they may be on hand to begin 
work as soon as the books are received. 
3. When they are received check each book opposite its author’s 
name in the dictionary catalog; check it also on agent’s bill. 
4, Enter each volume in the Condensed accession book, following 
rules at beginning of the book. 
5. Out leaves, taking great care to run the knife the full length of 
the fold. 
6. Emboss book on the title page and on all full-page illustrations. 
Embossing the book on certain other pages, to be decided on by each 
library, forms a convenient private mark—e. g., a library started in 
1893 may emboss the book on the ninth page and on the last page con- 
taining the figure 3. 
7. Paste book plate on middle of inside of first cover of each volume. 
The book plate should be 5 by 7.5 centimeters (2 by 3 inches) in size, 
of a strong bond paper, and of an azure tint. 
  
Class Book 
Altruria Public Library 
J 
20503——11 xvil 
 
-P-A-G-E-18
XVUI DIRECTIONS 
8, Paste label on back of each volume. The lower edge of the label 
should be 3.5 centimeters (1.4 inches) from the bottom of the book. Use 
Dennison’s wngummed labels, size A16. 
For book plates and labels the committee obtained excellent results 
by the use of Higgins’ Drawing board mucilage. 
9. Decide whether to use the Decimal or Expansive form of classifica- 
tion. (See pages 37-256 and 259, and compare call numbers* opposite 
each entry in the dictionary catalog.) 
10, Find call number for each book by looking under its author in 
the dictionary catalog. Write its call number on the book plate, 
placing the characters in the first column after the word “Class,” and 
the characters in the second column after the word “Book.” 
Take e. g. Lyman Abbott’s “Evolution of Christianity.” Look under 
Abbott in the dictionary catalog. It will be found on page 263. If the 
Decimal classification is used, write 201 after “Class” on book plate, 
Ab2after “Book.” If Expansive is used, write Co after “Class” and 
-Ab2 after “ Book.” 
Write call number on the Dennison label on the back of the book, 
class numbert above book number;t{ e. g. 201 or, Cc 
Ab2 -Ab2 
For classifying new books use directions in preface of Dewey’s “ Deci- 
mal classification” or Cutter’s “Expansive classification,” both in the 
A.L, A.library. In the Decimal, classify in most cases only to three 
figures, but in history and travel carry out the numbers to the country. 
In the Expansive, use the sixth classification. j prefixed to a call 
number means that the book is juvenile. 
For assigning book numbers to new books, use Cutter’s “‘Alfabetic- 
order table.” It is accompanied by a pamphlet giving directions for its 
use. 
Or for current books use class and bool numbers given on vrinted 
catalog cards, see below. 
  SIZE DIRECTIONS 
Decimal Expansive 
Octavo and below prefix . to book number. 
*Quarto prefix q to book number, prefix + to book number. 
*Folio prefix f to book number. prefix || to book number. 
*Omit last figure of number as found in Cutter table. 
11. Order printed catalog cards or slips from the Library Bureau or 
from the Rudolph Indexer Company. Both firms furnish them for a 
classified catalog (Decimal and Expansive), and for a dictionary cata- 
log, with full directions for their arrangement and use. Consult the 
firm of whom you purchase catalog cards as to the best appliances for 
their storage.   
*Call number. The combination of class and book number. 
tClass number. A number, letter or combination indicating the subject of a book 
and showing also its location on the shelves. 
+Book number. A number, letter or other character or combination of characters, 
used to distinguish an individual book from all others having the same class number.
-P-A-G-E-19
     DIRECTIONS xIxX 
  For new books, use Cutter’s “Rules for a dictionary catalog” and 
Dewey’s “Library School card catalog rules,” both in the A. L. A. 
library. Or for current books use Library Bureau or Rudolph printed 
eards or slips. 
12. Arrange books on shelves by call numbers on labels on the backs 
of the books. They will therefore stand in the order of entries in this 
catalog, either Classed catalog: Decimal, pages 37-144, or Classed. 
catalog: Expansive, pages 145-256, except folio volumes which must 
be shelved by themselves. 
Fiction and biography should be placed near the charging desk, 
arranged alphabetically in two groups like pages 1-16 and 19-36. 
For collected biography see note, page 16. 
Allow space for new books. Use book supports, either Crocker or 
L. B., about one to a shelf. 
13. Use this catalog, either Classed catalog: Decimal, or Classed 
catalog: Expansive, as a shelf list for taking the annual inventory. 
For new books a supplemental shelf list should be made on sheets 
according to rules found in “Library School rules.” Or a shelf list 
could be made with a duplicate set of printed catalog cards or slips, 
arranged in classified order. 
14. Decide on the charging system which seems best suited to the 
library. Twelve systems were selected as representative and exhibited 
by working models at Chicago. 
Awards were made for the following systems: Newark (N. J.) Public 
library; Apprentices’ library, New York city; Boston Atheneum 
library. 
15. In all discrepancies between the classed and dictionary catalog, 
follow the latter.

      BIOGRAPHY 
Individual Biography 
  This should be arranged on the shelves alphabetically by the names of the persons whose lives are 
told. In the Decimal classification B or 92 is prefixed to the author numbers as given below. In 
the Expansive classification E is prefixed, and lives of artists are exceptions, being classified with 
the ‘subject.

Collected Biography 
In this library collected biography is arranged alphabetically on the shelves by authors. In the 
“Decimal classification it is classified under 920; in the Expansive classification, with the subject. 
‘The two class numbers appear with each book in the dictionary catalog. 
Adams, 0.F. Brief handbook of American authors. 1884. D. Houghton, 
T5e. Adi 
Allibone, S$; A. Critical dictionary of English literature. 1891. 3v. Q. 
Lippincott, $22.50 qAl 
Supplement; by J: F. Kirk. 1892. 2v.Q. Lippincott, $15. v. 4-5 of  qAl 
Appletons’ cyclopedia of American biography. 1888-92. 6v. Q. Apple- 
ton, half morocco $42, cl. $30. gAp

FICTION 
Fiction in a popular library shonld be arranged on the shelves alphabetically by anthors. A great saving is effected by omitting the class number entirely and using only the author number, ‘The printed fiction list should contain author and title entries for each book. If for economy's sale one must be omitted, the title entries should be retained. Author entries are here chosen because serving better the main purpose of-this catalog, the selection and purchase of books.
